outcomes.title: Welcome
outcomes.plan: Geography of Asia

outcomes.title: About me
outcomes.plan: background, teaching, extra-curricular

outcomes.title: About you
outcomes.plan: login to school gmail, visit outline, submit personal reflection and new photo (optional)

outcomes.title: How this course will work?
outcomes.plan: pre-assess, teacher review it and go through outline, evaluations and expectations
outcomes.resource: How I will be evaluated on my learning skills

outcomes.title: How should I take notes?
outcomes.plan: create folder on Google Drive and share it to me, create a Google Doc inside, exit ticket

lessons.name: ArcGIS Online and Asia Country Data

outcomes.title: ArcGIS online
outcomes.plan: Demo logging in to ArcGIS online (user: first.last password: pw$arcgis2016)

outcomes.title: Search and map a data layer
outcomes.plan: Demo searching for a data layer in your organization using keyword 'country'
outcomes.resource: How to search and add a layer

outcomes.title: Examine Asian continent and identify countries
outcomes.plan: Use ArcGIS online tools to identify countries, view attributes and pan and zoom

outcomes.title: Asia Country Song
outcomes.plan: Students listen and sing along!

outcomes.title: Asia Country Sporcle
outcomes.plan: Complete Sporcle for Asian countries and prepare for quiz

outcomes.title: Asia country quiz
outcomes.plan: How many of the 48 countries can you identify?

outcomes.title: Symbolizing features using attributes in ArcGIS
outcomes.plan: Teacher Demo

outcomes.title: ArcGIS lab: Religions of Asia
outcomes.plan: Students complete lab and submit lab as their class notes in exit ticket

outcomes.title: Quiz
outcomes.plan: Distribution of religions

outcomes.title: What is a region?
outcomes.plan: Students create a definition and examples of different regions in Asia for their notes

outcomes.title: Regions layer
outcomes.plan: Teacher demo regions layer from ArcGIS Online
outcomes.note: 5 regions as defined by UN Geoscheme

outcomes.title: Example: Central Asia
outcomes.plan: students brainstorm why they think this is a region
outcomes.note: ethnicity nomadic peoples, history of silk road from Europe to China, recently much of area under domination of USSR, desert and steppe or plains

outcomes.title: What is an intelligence brief?
outcomes.plan: Students watch video and ask questions
outcomes.note: Research analysts prepare a short

outcomes.title: Introduce Intelligence Brief example and assignment
outcomes.plan: Students review example, ask questions and make a copy to reside in their Geography folder on Google Drive

outcomes.title: Brief rubric
outcomes.plan: Students review and submit self review and ask questions

outcomes.title: Work period
outcomes.plan: students research UN regions, complete attached document, and show teacher to choose one - first come ...

outcomes.title: How to make a map of my region?
outcomes.plan: Teacher demo filter functionality

outcomes.title: How to create MLA citations easily?
outcomes.plan: Teacher demo easybib

outcomes.title: Work period
outcomes.plan: students work on their Google Doc

outcomes.title: Check-in on progress
outcomes.plan: teacher checks-in with students and students submit Exit Ticket with link to Google Doc

outcomes.title: What is population distribution?
outcomes.plan: Teacher show graphic, students guess
outcomes.note: Distribution refers to the way something is spread out or arranged over a geographic area (pattern).

outcomes.title: Practice identifying distribution patterns
outcomes.plan: Students download and label one of each pattern (like example). Label 2 surprises. Attach to your notes

lessons.name: Countries with high and low density

outcomes.title: What is population density?
outcomes.plan: Students find definition online and ask questions
outcomes.note: People per square km.

outcomes.title: What factors affect population density?
outcomes.plan: Students review document and ask questions
outcomes.note: Population distribution is uneven. Some areas are more dense than others. What are some factors that affect this?

outcomes.title: ArcGIS Online lab 2 - Population Density in Asia
outcomes.plan: Students complete lab and submit lab as their class notes in exit ticket

outcomes.title: Quiz
outcomes.plan: Factors that affect density and countries with high and low density

lessons.name: Cradles of civilization: Asia's great rivers and cities

outcomes.title: Civilization started in Asia
outcomes.plan: Students watch video and try to understand why civilizations grow around rivers and 3 ancient Asian examples
outcomes.note: flat, nutriant rich soil, reliable water - examples: Mesopotamia (Tigres and Euphrates), Indus valley, Yellow valley

outcomes.title: Rise of the Asian Mega-city
outcomes.plan: students click through article, taking notes

outcomes.title: River online Quiz
outcomes.plan: Complete this onine quiz to learn about the major rivers of Asia

outcomes.title: River Quiz
outcomes.plan: Big 13 rivers of Asia

outcomes.title: Cities online Quizzes
outcomes.plan: Complete onine quizzes to learn about the major cities of Asia

outcomes.title: Megacity Quiz
outcomes.plan: Big 24 cities of Asia

outcomes.title: Subregions of Asia: United Nations geoscheme
outcomes.plan: Teacher remind students about 25 common subregions defined by UN

outcomes.title: ArcGIS Online lab 4 - Asian regions
outcomes.plan: Students complete lab and submit lab as their class notes in exit ticket

outcomes.title: Regions Quiz
outcomes.plan: Regions and landform terninology

outcomes.title: What is climate?
outcomes.note: Climate is NOT the atmospheric conditions right here, right now (weather)

outcomes.title: How can climates be classified?
outcomes.plan: Students read article and make notes
outcomes.note: Toronto is between Dfb (warm summer like Winnipeg) and Dfa (hot summer like Chicago)

outcomes.title: ArcGIS Online lab 5 - Asian climates
outcomes.plan: Students complete lab and submit lab as their class notes in exit ticket

outcomes.title: Climates Quiz
outcomes.plan: Climates and Koppen-Geiger classification system

outcomes.title: How many Overseas Chinese are there?
outcomes.plan: students complete quick web research on Chinese diaspora - compile stats and links for your notes
outcomes.note: 40-50 million, mostly in Southeast Asia

outcomes.title: How many Overseas Chinese are there in Toronto?
outcomes.plan: students complete quick web research - compile stats and links for your notes
outcomes.note: 11% of Toronto, 20%+ in suburbs - do the math!

outcomes.title: Where are 'China-towns' in Toronto?
outcomes.plan: students complete quick web research - compile stats and links for your notes
outcomes.note: There are up to 6 Chinatowns in Toronto - the biggest at Spadina and Dundas

outcomes.title: Mandarin vs Cantonese: Cantonese wins in downtown
outcomes.plan: Students watch video and compile differences for notes
outcomes.note: Mandarin has 935M speakers to 60M Cantonese (centred around Hong Kong in southern China), but the latter remains the primary language used by businesses and restaurants in Chinatown

outcomes.title: North vs South - The Rice Theory
outcomes.plan: Students read article and take notes
outcomes.note: China can be divided north - south by the Yangze River (Chang Jiang). North is the wheat belt and south the rice belt.

outcomes.title: Field trip notes
outcomes.plan: students review information about our trip

outcomes.title: Group shot
outcomes.plan: geo students in the field
outcomes.note: Very serious data collection and cultural appreciation going on - and a bit of fun too

outcomes.title: Data and Mapping
outcomes.plan: students download data as CSV and drag into ArcGIS Online map

outcomes.title: Create map
outcomes.plan: students screenshot map and write a conclusion about distribution of Chinese businesses and diversity in Chinatown

outcomes.title: Topics and format
outcomes.plan: students review topics and format

outcomes.title: What are some wealthy nations in Asia?
outcomes.plan: students brainstorm a list
outcomes.note: Quatar, Macau, Singapore, Israel ... any big guys? Japan

outcomes.title: How do we measure wealth?
outcomes.plan: think/pair/share
outcomes.note: GDP / capita ... is there a better way? PPP

outcomes.title: ArcGIS Online lab 6 - Wealth of Nations
outcomes.plan: Students copy and complete lab and submit lab as their class notes in exit ticket

outcomes.title: Wealth Quiz
outcomes.plan: Rates

lessons.name: The Dragon Awakes: The Chinese development model
lessons.unit: UNIT 2: The Dragon and its neighbours

outcomes.title: The Dragon Awakes: 2000 years of economic history in one graph
outcomes.plan: students make copy of document, read and complete work sheet

outcomes.title: China's development model since 1978
outcomes.plan: students make copy, read and complete work sheet

outcomes.title: Special Economic Zones
outcomes.plan: students review slide - learn coastal, interior, western and waves of SEZ creation
outcomes.note: 50%+ of China GDP comes from SEZ - coastal Shenzen, Shantou (1980), Tianjin, Shanghai (1984), all capital cities of inland provinces and selected border cities (1992), Kashgar in far western China near the Stans (2010)

outcomes.title: Complete exit ticket
outcomes.plan: students complete worksheets and then link to them in their lesson document, complete vocab and do exit ticket

outcomes.title: Quiz
outcomes.plan: students demonstrate understanding of economic reforms and main rivers and cities

lessons.name: The Largest Migration in human history

outcomes.title: Most of China's population is in the relatively flat coastal plain or river valleys
outcomes.plan: students review Hu Huanyong line - what part is the core and what is the periphery of China?

outcomes.title: 23 provinces, 4 municipalities, 5 autonomous regions and two special administrative zones
outcomes.plan: students research sub-national districts and map them by name and type

outcomes.title: China provinces quiz
outcomes.plan: students take the test until they get 75%

outcomes.title: The largest internal migration in human history
outcomes.plan: students watch video and complete worksheet

lessons.name: Distribution of wealth and quality of life in China

outcomes.title: Provincial economy equivalents
outcomes.plan: students compare China's provincial economies to Ontario

outcomes.title: Quality of life disparity between provinces
outcomes.plan: students define HDI, put map in notes and make conclusions on regional differences (coastal | inland | western)
outcomes.note: Ontario and Canada are both rated .913 on HDI scale - very high - how do Chinese provinces fare?

outcomes.title: Rich Province, Poor Province - Regional Development Strategies
outcomes.plan: students read article and take notes

outcomes.title: Future mega-projects in China
outcomes.plan: students watch video and take notes

outcomes.title: Focus on the 3-Gorges Dam
outcomes.plan: students read article and complete questions

outcomes.title: What is your perspective on the 3-Gorges mega-project?
outcomes.plan: students watch video and formulate their own perspective [10 marks]
outcomes.note: Take a postion, SEPE (3 good reasons with examples for), think of counter argument, then refute or dilute it, then conclude

outcomes.title: What is an info-graphic? - urbanization in China
outcomes.plan: students review and critique infographic
outcomes.note: 1980 200m people lived in Chinese cities, now it is 700m+ - equavilent to adding urban infrastructure (housing, roads, jobs etc) for population of Canada, USA and Mexico

outcomes.title: What should mine look like?
outcomes.plan: teacher show example project - posters on the wall with rubrics beside

outcomes.title: How will I be evaluated?
outcomes.plan: teacher answer questions about the rubric

outcomes.title: How do I make the infographic?
outcomes.plan: students watch video
outcomes.note: ArcGIS online, QGIS, ScapeToad, MS Excel and MS Powerpoint - WOW!

outcomes.title: ScapeToad?
outcomes.plan: students download, install ScapeToad and move files to a new folder in Applications

lessons.name: Will China become the most powerful country?

outcomes.title: China continues to challenge the USA, but will it become the greater power?
outcomes.plan: students read and complete vocab and questions

lessons.name: Territorial disputes and exclusive economic zones

outcomes.title: Territorial disputes between China and Japan
outcomes.plan: students watch video to get an idea of the disputes that are out there

outcomes.title: ArcGIS lab - EEZ and 9 dashed line
outcomes.plan: students make a copy and complete
outcomes.note: China is attempting to gain sovereignty over the South China Sea. Many say it is to regain prestige, take control of valuable trade routes, access marine and sub-surface resources and establish a military presence for a future conflict

outcomes.title: Who has a stake in the South China Sea sovereignty territorial dispute?
outcomes.plan: students review 9 dashed line and EEZ map
outcomes.note: China, Taiwan, Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia

outcomes.title: Why is sovereignty so important in the South China Sea?
outcomes.plan: students do research to find 3 facts on importance of SCS
outcomes.note: trade, marine and sub-surface resources, military, prestige

outcomes.title: What is the status of the China vs. Philippines tribunal?
outcomes.plan: students read article and make notes
outcomes.note: China lost, but refuses to accept the findings of UNCLOS

outcomes.title: Form partners and assign stakeholder
outcomes.plan: students find a partner and teacher assign a stakeholder to each

outcomes.title: How will we be evaluated?
outcomes.plan: students review rubric and ask questions

outcomes.title: Stakeholder research and preparation
outcomes.plan: students perform initial research and prepare for their 10 minute presentation

outcomes.plan: students complete quiz

outcomes.title: Quiz
outcomes.plan: student take provinces and seas quiz

lessons.name: Getting to know Indonesia - ArcGIS lab

outcomes.title: ArcGIS lab
outcomes.plan: students complete the lab

lessons.name: Trade Flows: Strait of Malacca or the Kra Isthmus Canal?

outcomes.title: Tankers clog the Malacca Strait at Phillips Channel (2.5km) in Singapore
outcomes.plan: students, why there is such congestion here?

outcomes.title: Piracy around the Malay Peninsula
outcomes.plan: ask students why there are attacks here?

outcomes.title: Malacca Strait or Kra Canal - Note taking exercise
outcomes.plan: students make copy of Google Doc and use for directed note taking
outcomes.expectation: D2.2 analyse key aspects of trade in this region, including trade among countries within the region as well as with those elsewhere in the world, D3.5 analyse the advantages and disadvantages of foreign investment for this region, with reference, as appropriate, to countries that invest and those that attract investment

lessons.name: Indonesia in ASEAN: First among equals?

outcomes.title: ASEAN notes
outcomes.plan: students watch videos and read wiki page to complete structured notes - use as Notes in Exit Ticket
outcomes.expectation: D2.2 analyse key aspects of trade in this region, including trade among countries within the region as well as with those elsewhere in the world

outcomes.title: Indonesia: The Germany of ASEAN?
outcomes.plan: students read article and answer questions - paste questions/answers into your notes

outcomes.title: Crash Course video and VOC notes template

outcomes.expectation: D3.4 explain the benefits and disadvantages of the operations of multinational corporations [MNCs] in the region, C1.2 assess the effects, both positive and negative, on the region of outside demand for its products and/or resources (deforestation)

outcomes.plan: students make copy and complete - use this as notes on Exit Ticket

outcomes.expectation: E3.1 explain how various factors affect weather and climate patterns in the region, E3.3 identify natural hazards to which the region is vulnerable

outcomes.plan: students watch documentary
outcomes.expectation: E3.2 explain how climate change currently affects the region and how it is likely to do so in the future, A2.3 apply the concepts of geographic thinking when analysing current events involving geographic issues
